edition.title: Alexander von Humboldt auf Reisen - Wissenschaft aus der Bewegung

note.p: Im März 1825 hielt sich der schottische Botaniker George Arnott Walker-Arnott in Paris auf. Dort fertigte er auf Bitten Humboldts diese Liste zur Geographie der Moose an. Die am oberen Rand der ersten Seite eingetragene Sigle B verweist auf die Nummer 10 der von Karl Sigismund Kunth 1825 angelegten Ideensammlung zur Neuausgabe der Geographie der Pflanzen („Verbreitung der Moose“). Bereits 1822 hatte Walker-Arnott für Humboldt eine Auflistung von Moosen angefertigt, die sowohl in der nördlichen Hemisphäre als auch in den Tropen vorkommen. Sie trägt in der Kunth'schen Materialsammlung die Sigle L. Auf die erste Seite des Dokuments montierte Humboldt ein Blatt mit Exzerpten aus Thomas Edward Bowdichs 1825 „Excursions in Madeira and Porto Santo“ (Bowdich 1825). Die auf diesem Blatt angegebene Sigle C korrespondiert ebenfalls mit Nummer 10 der Kunth'schen Materialsammlung.

div.p: Andreea.

p.note:
C.
Filices
abondent dans les
îles. Dicksonia
ou arbor. arborescent ferns pas
trouvé à Madère Vgl. Thomas Edward Bowdichs Bericht über seine Exkursion nach São Vicente während seines Aufenthaltes auf Madeira (Bowdich 1825, 49–50): Here I first saw the beautiful fern asplenium palmatum. The filices form by far the most interesting family in Madeira, verifying Baron de Humboldt's remark, that their maximum may be found in the mountainous parts of small islands [...], yet I was disappointed at not finding the dicksonia mentioned by the above author [...].
H
Bodwich Bowdich
Tr. Travels
Bowdich 1825.
p page 49.
Vermilia bicarina
ta et
Galeoloria elongata
de
Nouv Nouvelle
Holl Hollande
trouvé à
Madère
Bodw. Bowd.
Bowdich
p page 63!
Géographie des
plantes de
Madère
Bodw Bowd
Bowdich
p page 101, 152,
248

div.p:
This genus is, as far as I have been enabled to deter
mine, confined wholly to Europe: it occurs on the mountains in moun
tainous
districts usually at very considerable elevations. There are
only four species; those which were known to Linné were
confounded by him with Jungermannia.

I consider that there are only four species of this genus
two of which at least are very widely distributed: Sph. Sphagnum
latifolium occurs in all the marshes of throughout all
Europe. I possess
it also from North america, where I believe it is very wide
ly dist as abundant as in Europe: Michaux has called it
S. Sphagnum
vulgare. It is described by Bridel from the straits of
Magellan under the name of S. Sphagnum
magellanicum. In the
Isles of Bourbon, France, and New Holland, (and I believe
also in East India) it has also been found. Sphagnum
acutifolium seems nearly as widely distributed, but I
do not recollect of having observed S. Sphagnum
squarrosum, or S. Sphagnum cus
pidatium as occuring out of Europe. Some botanists,
and I think with justice, consider that there is only one
species of this genus.

This genus may be considered as nearly European, & the
species are nearly confinded, as far as has been hitherto observed
to the middle districts of Europe. To the north the species become
few, and finally disappear in the Arctic circle: About the middle & South
of England, Germany, & France, they are found in considerable
numbers, but, whether through the negligence of botanists I
know not, but they are scarcely at all found farther south.
A few of the European species have been found in North a
merica in Pensylvania Pennsylvania , among these are Ph. Phascum subulatum, rectum
crispum, patens, cuspidatum, crassinervium, and perhaps a few others: I consider
Ph. Phascum stenophyllum of Voit to be only a variety of; of these Ph. Phascum subu
latum has I believe also been found in New Holland. Ph. Phascum co
herens and Ph. Phascum flexuosum are perhaps the only two confined exclu
sively to N. North America ( Pensylvania Pennsylvania ). Ph. Phascum alternifolium occurs
in Great Britain, in Germany, and, if I mistake not at the
Cape of Good Hope and (if Bridel's Pleuridium be, as I suppose, the
2 same plant), also in the Isle of France. Phascum nervosum and splachnoi
deum have been found, & are peculiar to the Cape of Good Hope.

Thus it may be said that this genus is confined entirely to tem
perate regions: moreover it is seldom (never?) found at any
great elevation, seldom at more than 6 or 8 hundred feet 100 or
150 hexapod. hexapodes
– all occur on the ground.
Bruchia.

This which consists of only one species differs from the last
genus, & is intermediate between it & the following in all
its characters: It has the general appearance of the last, but
approaches more closely the characters of the following: it
occurs at a considerable elevation on the mountains of the Vosges.
Voitia.

Of the two species, the one, V. Voitia nivalis occurs at a great
altitude on the Carinthian mountains, at the limits of perpe
tual snow "in stercore vaccino". The other was first discovered in
Melville Island, but has since been found on the coasts of
Hudsons bay, & at the mouth of the coppermine river.
Gymnostomum.

This numerous genus, consisting of upwards of 30 species,
is very widely distributed: One section (3 species) is found entirely
at the cape, and has been constituted a separate genus by
both Brown, and Schwägrichen under the name of Glypho
carpa. Perhaps a Bartramia which has been found both
elsewhere in Africa, & might be added. Of the other or real Gymnostoma, there
are two sections, of which the one is chiefly alpine, the other
is not confined to any particular situation. Of the first
of these, nearly all are European: one is however belongs to arctic america,
and two of the others to Nepal
G. Gymnostomum xanthocarpon and G. Gymnostomum
nepalense Nob. Nobis to Nepal, one of the European species ( G. Gymnostomum aestivum) was found by Schmidt on Teneriffe, all grow on rock, with the excep
tion of G. Gymnostomum viridissimum, a British species, which is more com
monly found on the southern exposure of trees – Of the
other section there are about 15 or 16 found in Europe. Of these
one,
G. Gymnostomum Griffithianum, is peculiar to the mountains of Wales, England, & Scotland,
the others are chiefly found in the low countries. G. Gymnostomum fasciculare
has been found through the whole world: it may be traced
in Hindostan under the name of G. Gymnostomum Rottleri, and perhaps
in Japan under that of G. Gymnostomum japonicum; G. Gymnostomum pyriforme is found
as commonly in the United States as in Europe, & I have obser
3ved it in Mr. Mister Burchell's herbarium from the Cape of Good Hope.
G. Gymnostomum truncatulum is diffused widely through Europe and Asia.
I do not recollect of think that there is any species peculiar to North america.
But in South america we have G. Gymnostomum julaceum (Quito. alt. altitudine
2300 hexap. hexapodum )– G. Gymnostomum Bonplandii (New Granada
alt. altitudine
1300 hexap hexapodum ),
G. Gymnostomum jamesoni (Rio janeiro), and another species from Mendoza (Chili). – One species has
been found on Mount atlas in africa, another in Madeira – and another in Nepal and
G. Gy mnostomum
in
volutum in Nepal which also occurs in Java under the
name of G. Gymnostomum javanicum. Upon the whole this genus
may be considered as belonging to the temperate regions.
Schistostega.

The only gererally acknowledged plant of this genus is
S. Schistostega pennata is in & has hitherto been found only in the middle
of Europe, as Germany & the South of England. A plant
however which perhaps belongs to the genus, the Drepano
phyllum fulvum of Richard & Hooker, but very little
understood, has been found by Richard in the woods
of Cayenne, Isle de Bourbon, & Hispaniola.
Anictangium.

A. Anictangium pulvinatum, subsessile, and caespititium caespiticium , are
peculiar to the middle of Europe, & may be considered
as subalpine species. A. Anictangium ciliatum occurs every where in the temperate regions.
In Europe it is extremely common: in North america
particularly in the United states it is equally so, though
of a darker green colour, and has been by some erroneously
thought distinct under the name of Hedwigia integrifolia
& Anictangium filiforme: Brown found it in New-
Holland, & I have it is plentiful in Nepal. A. Anictangium torquatum
is peculiar to South america (Banks of the Amazons in New
Granada – and in Brazil) – A. Anictangium repens has only been found on the
West coast of New Holland.
Hedwigia.

One species is confined to South of Europe, H. Hedwigia aquatica; the only other
two species were brought by M. M. Humboldt and Bonpland,
of these H. Hedwigia secunda has only hitherto been found in Mexi
co, near Tolucca at an alt. altitude of 1300 hexap. hexapodes the other
Hed. Humboldtii, found on Quindíu at an alt. altitude of 1.600, has
been also found at no great distance from the Cape
of G. Good Hope; and if (as I suspect) Hypnum nigrocaule nigricaule
and
4
H. Hedwigia taxiforme be the same as this, I may add to these
localities the isle of Gaudeloupe, & the South sea islands.
Diphyscium & Buxbaumia.

Both these genera are common
to the middle of Europe & North america. They are usually occur in
Subalpine districts, i. e. id est about 100, or 150 hexap. hexapodes above the
sea.

All the species may be considered as more or
less alpine. They usually are most numerous in the
middle and northern parts of Europe and N. North america.
S. Splachnum ampullaceum, sphaericum, & tenue are usually met with south of the arctic
circle & are probably confinded to Europe. S. Splachnum angustatum
is more common both in
Europe towards the arctic circle
but soon again disappears, it occurs in the Unnorthern parts of the United
states. S. Splachnum vasculosum has a wide range: it occurs in
both continents, even to Melville island. Sp. Splachnum urceolatum
is I believe wholly European, and is most frequent in
Lapland. S. Splachnum mnioides is common in the mountains of Europe,
and if S. Splachnum arcticum, propinquum, & exsertum of Brown be the same,
it also occurs in the arctic regions of N. North america: S. Splachnum worm
skioldii has been was first found in Greenland, but has
since been found, growing to a size 10, or 12 times greater
in all the arctic america that the several English expedi
tions have reached to: S. Splachnum adamsonianum has been
found in Kamtschatka, & arctic america (under the name of
S. Splachnum paradoxum Brown): S. Splachnum luteum and rubrum are confound
within the arctic circle of Europe, but the former occurs
also within the same latitudes in North America. Lastly
Sp. Splachnum longicollum, if really different from S. Splachnum tenue, has only
been found on the North West Coast of N. North america. S. Splachnum
magellanicum, at the Straights Straits of Magellan, & S. Splachnum octo
blepharum in New Holland.

This
D. Dissodon
splachnoides, Hornschuchii, and Froelichianum
are European, and are found at very great elevations
in the Middle and Northern parts. D. Dissodon scabrisetum (Splachnum
Scabrisetum. Humb. Humbold t ) has been only procured by MM
Humb. Humboldt & Bonpland
at in
S. South america (Jaén de Bracamoros. alt. altitude
1100 hexap. hexapodes )

has only been found in the middle of Europe, at very great
elevations.

pellucida is found in Europe & north america the united
states, at
no great small
elevations. There are other three species
but these are confined wholly to the middle parts of Europe.
Octoblepharum.

Common in the West India islands, as Jamaica,
S.t Saint Vincents &c, in Africa
as at Ouare, in Cayenne, Basil Brazil , isles de Bourbon, & Isle de
France, Madagascar, Nepal and other parts in the East indies.

First found in the isle de Bourbon, but now in the
the
greatest profusion in Nepal.
Calymperes.

Not one species is European: Indeed it may be
called a tropical genus. C. Calymperes lonchophyllum is found
in Cayenne, Brazil &c. C. Calymperes Palisoti at Ouare in africa,
in the isles of Granada, S.t Saint Thomas, S.t Saint Vincents; Brazil, Nepal, Prince
of Wales Island, and the Moluccas (for I consider C. Calymperes moluccen
sis as the same species). C Calymperes afzelii, if different from the
last, is found in Africa.
C. Calymperes Berterii is found in Hispaniola,
C. Calymperes Swartzii (Eucalypta parasitiea Schw.
Sw. Swartz ) in the West
Indies – C. Calymperes Gardneri, & C. Calymperes Taylori in Nepal – Three or
four other species are found in the isle of S.t Saint Vincent,
& one or two more in the Moluccas. – All of them
seem to grow on trees.

Zygo Zygodon conoideum is dispersed throughout Europe.
Z. Zygodon menziesii in New Zealand, New Holland, &c. and
Z. Zygodon obtusifolium in Nepal. All I believe on the trunks
of trees.

This genus is too extensive to examine the species
separately: it is sufficent to say that the it is very
generally distributed. The species occurring in Europe &
N. North america have usually a very different appearence
from those to the South, so much so as to induce
some muscologists to retain the former only in this
genus; & they have accordingly constituted two new
genera for the remainder. But some species as O. Orthotrichum diapha
num is found not only in Europe, but at Mendoça (in Chili),
6others from the tropics, as O. Orthotrichum plicatum, of there are only about
10 or 12 peculiar to Europe, about 4 4 or 5 to North america
(betwixt the united states & the arctic regions), at least
5 or 6 common to Europe & North america, one to Europe
& South america, and the remainder, about 40 in number, seemed pretty much
confined to their respective countries, they are about
which may be said to be chiefly tropical; a few only
as Otaheita, Nepal, New Zealand, Van Diemens-land,
Cape of Good Hope being out of that range, & and not
many species are hitherto discovered in these.

Only one species which is confined to the sea coasts
of Great Britain England & Ireland.

Of this genus, containing about 27 or 28 species, nearly 20 are
confined to Europe, scarcely more than two to North america
(the united states), one, G. Grimmia apocarpa with its varieties & perhaps G. Grimmia maritima seems
common to both. G. Grimmia fontinaloides, longisotris, and fuscolutea, belongs to S. South america;
and G. Grimmia campestris to the Cape of Good hope: The European species
are principally alpine, but some are found as G. Grimmia maritima are
found at the level of the sea, others as G. Grimmia apacarpa occur in all
situations, which from the slight variations that in consequence takes take
place on the appearance of the plant, has received six or eight
different names. It is singular that G. Grimmia pulvinata, β. africana, brought
by Thunberg from the Cape of Good hope, & which perhaps with
justice should be held as a distinct species, or perhaps the more
probably the same with G. Grimmia fuscolutea from S. South America, has been
said to have been found in Swisserland. As however I have
not yet seen either, I cannot give my opinion decidedly.
Of the South american ones G. Grimmia fontinaloides is analogous to our
European
G. Grimmia apocarpa var. varietas rivularis – G. Grimmia longirostris to the European
G. Grimmia ovata – and lastly G. Grimmia fuscolutea to the G. Grimmia pulvinata. Of the
South african species, G. Grimmia campestris resembles G. Grimmia leucophaea so
closely as with difficulty to be separated, and G. Grimmia africana, supposing
it distinct, is very closely allied to G. Grimmia pulvinata. Thus an
opinion that there are only three species of this genus would gain
some confirmation, & that these species were distributed all over
the globe: the three species would be 1. with immersed setae, 2. with
exserted straight setae, & 3. with excerted incurved setae.

Of the Genuine Trichostoma, the greater part are European
and are most plentiful in the mountainous, or subalpine dis
stricts: a few are found in North america, but there are none pe
culiar to it, all of them likewise occurring in Europe: thus For
T. Trichostomum Cana
dense is only a variety of identical with
T. Trichostomum canescens. & T. Trichostomum obtusi
folium is noways different from T. Trichostomum aciculare. T. Trichostomum lanugi
nosum is
found every
where – in
Chili, Mexico,
&c. Of the true Tri
chostoma one or two species occur in Nepal. There is also
a section of spurious ones (with long vaginating perichaetia that
when better understood may be probably joined to a different
genus), T. Trichostomum perichaetiale, & cylindricum both in Hookers
Musci Exotici Hooker, J. D. 1818-1820.
that come the one from & the other from . One species T. Trichostomum polyphyllum seems very widely distributed; it has been found
in South America by M M. Humboldt & Bonpland, at at the cape of
Good Hope by Mr. Mister Burchell.
Cinclidotus.
this is entirely a European genus.
Eucalypta.

As far as I recollect the whole are European, there are only
four species, they are all alpine except the E. Eucalypta vulgaris.
Weissia.

I do not know that this genus occurs in South america, but
in Europe, North America, West Indies, Cape of Good Hope, Madagascar, the Moluccas,
& various of the South Sea Islands, it has bee found. Nearly
all however are European: and even when the a species is not Euro
pean, there is usually some one in Europe to which it bears an
affinity. Thus W. Weissia Radians from the South seas, & W. Weissia bergiana from
the cape are. Two or three species as W. Weissia controversa and W. Weissia verti
cillata are common to Europe & North America. The last has I understand been also found in the Canary Isles. W. Weissia curvirostra
extends from the West of Europe to Asia minor. Some of the
species are alpine, but many a few others are by no means so.
Tremadoton.

I consider that there is but one species of this genus: two of the
varieties occur in Europe, a third in the united states, and the
fourth in the island of Tristan d'Acunha, but there are intermediate
varieties from the same places. The European species occur as far South
as the Tyrolese Alps, & extend to Seeland.

Of the f one section (Fissidens Hedw. Hedwig ), D. Dicranum bryoides is found every
where. In Europe one finds it extremely common, as well as its va
rieties. I perhaps have seen it from N. North america (united States), from S. South america
(Rio janeero – Mendoça &c), West india Islands, the Cape, East
India, & various of the South Sea islands, nor can I find dif
8ferences sufficient to characterise a variety: it was the sight of
this very plant in the sandy deserts of Africa, that inspired the
traveller Mungo Park, when fatigued & overpowered with thirst as
he mentions in his travels, to push forward & endeavour to
procure some refreshment. – Another species of this section
D. Dicranum taxifolium has been traced in Nepal. and If Dicranum
(Fissidens) Semicompletum, and Skitophyllum fontanum, or Fontinalis juliana
be, as I suppose, identical it has been found both in Europe
& in the in Patagonia, isle of Providence, & perhaps the isles
of Bourbon. – Of another tribe of Dicrana, those with no
nerves to the leaf, & resembling Sphagnum in texture, one
D. Dicranum glaucum has been met with in nearly all parts of the
world: it occurs however more rarely within the tropics and
D. Dicranum megalophyllum (Sphagnum javense of Brid. Bridel ) takes its place.
In new Holland, a third species of this tribe appears to have been
sent to Dillenius, but perhaps his figure is only a bad represen
tation of a state of D. Dicranum glaucum which does occur there. – The
remainder of the Dicrana are nearly 40 in number, of which
scarcely more than 13 are confined to Europe, not above one or
two to North america; South america posseses the D. Dicranum vagina
tum, densum, and longisetum, and a few also are peculiar to Nepal.
But about 11 or 12, are common both to Europe & North america,
two or three to Europe & Nepal, about as many to Europe
and New Holland; Some species, which are met with in
Jamaica & the neighbouring islands, as D. Dicranum calycinum, occur also in
the isles of Bourbon. D. Dicranum crispum (an European species) is said
by Thumberg to grow at the cape, but I suspect his plant
to be D. Dicranum flexifolium, a species peculiar to that country. The most
widely diffused species of the whole genus is D. Dicranum scoparium, which
has been found in almost every country in the world. And another
species D. Dicranum Harkii is I suspect nearly as common, though at
present retaining different names.

This genus may be reckoned alpine, but with the excep
tion of Th. Thesanomitrion flexuosum, which occurs also most commonly in Europe, may be
considered belonging to the tropics. – Th. Thesanomitrion concolor (Dicranum
concolor Hook. Hooker ) from is only found
in New Granada occurs also in the Isle
of Bourbon and, a small variety, ? perhaps Th. Thesanomitrion capillaceum, not described in the Synopsis
to the „Nova Genera &c.“, seems not uncommon to be found in St. Saint Helena,
Ile of Bourbon, & the moluccas. Th. Thesanomitrion introflexum is perhaps the
9 most widely diffused, as it is found in almost every island within the
tropics.

Of this genus, the most generally diffused is Did. Didymodon purpureum: it
is not only common in Europe & North america, but extends to the
Canary isles, & the Cape of Good hope, as far as I recollect it is
also a common species in New Holland. – D. Didymodon pallidum ( Trichostom Trichostomum
pallidum Schw. Schwägrichen ) a plant perhaps nowhere abundant, is neverthe
less widely diffused. Europe, North America, Jamaica, Patagonia,
New Holland &c all posess it. D. Didymodon trifarium & heteromallus has been found both
in Europe & North america & perhaps a few others.

A considerable number are common both to Europe & North a
merica. A variety? of T. Tortula inclinata (a Swiss plant) has been at
the cape of good hope. T. Tortula membranifolia Hook. Hooker first detected
in Teneriffe, has since been observed in the Pyrenées, in Swisserland,
and even by in the environs of Paris! – T. Tortula muralis, occurs both
in Europe & S. South america (Rio Janeiro at
Mendoça), T. Tortula ruralis oc
curs every where. A few species are peculiar to North ameri
ca, as T. Tortula caespitosa, humilis, leucostoma; some are peculiar
to Nepal, as T. Tortula indica, flavescens, angustifolia; others are
peculiar to New Holland, others to the cape, others to the West Indies. T. Tortula cirrhata
(Trichostomum barbula Schw. Schwägrichen ) found in Portugal, occurs also
in Teneriffe, & a larger variety has been sent me from
Rio Janeiro. –{ N. B. Nota Bene
T. Tortula stellata of Jamaica, said by Dickson to grow in Scotland is probably
an error, there is reason to fear that he had confused his Scottish &
Jamaica plants together.

There are only two species; the one is confined to the
northern parts of Europe; as Scotland, Lapland &c, the other
to the straights Straits of Magellan.

So many disputes are at present as to what are species &
what are not so, in this genus, that it is difficult to say which
are peculiar to Europe & I rather think however that
B. Bartramia , Halleriana, Ithyphylla, & arcuata are the only three
that are not found elsewhere. B. Bartramia pomiformis occurs,
gracilis, & fontana, are also extremely common in North america. In
which country (the North West Coast), B. Bartramia menziesii has
only been found. B. Bartramia longifolia is peculiar to South america
(vide.
H. Humboldt & B. Bonpland synopsis Kunth 1822–1825, I, 55. ), but B. Bartramia patens , & stricta
have has also
been found there: the first of these B. Bartramia patens This was found
10 by
M. M. Messieurs
Humbt. Humboldt & Bonpd. Bonpland
Kunth 1822–1825, I, 55. , it also occurs at the straights Straits of Ma
gellan, and in isle of Bourbon? – the other another , B. Bartramia stricta is
said to be found at the
straights Straits of Magellan, and on but is probably regular to the coast of
Barbary. Bartramia fontana is found every where:
Europe, N. North america, East & West indies, NewHolland, Ota
heita, Cape of Good Hope, &c.., Bartamia tomentosa
from Jamaica, is very closely allied to, but must not be
confounded with B. Bartramia arcuata of Europe.

Some authors begin to suspect that all the species are not
different from each other: but be that as it may, the
common F. Funaria hygrometrica of Europe is as common in N. North america.
It is found also, (growing with a species F. Funaria calvescens, which
is purely tropical,) in South america, as at Rio janeiro,
& Quito (? v. vide
H. Humboldt & B. Bonpland synopsis Kunth 1822–1825, I, 56. ). – F. Funaria flavicans is found in
North & South america, and F. Funaria muhlenbergii is common
to the United States & the middle of Europe.
This is entirely an Australasian genus.

Both All Three species have been only found in Nepal.
only in Europe.
Brown mentions that there is ano
ther from Arctic america.

This genus is but little known, it has been found
at Port jackson in New Holland.
Both species have been only found in Nepal.

This & most of the following genera contain so many species
that I shall here briefly point out a few of the
species that are most widely diffused.
1. Bryum palustre – Europe & North america
2. B. Bryum turgidum – Lapland and Actic america.
3. B. Bryum longisetum – North of Europe, & Arctic america.
4. B. Bryum argenteum – Europe, North america, S. South america (as
in Brazil, Mexico) Cape of Good Hope, Nepal,
New Holland, &c...
5. B. Bryum julaceum – Europe,
N. North america, S. South america ( v. vide
H. Humboldt
& B. Bonpland synopsis Kunth 1822–1825, I, 57. ), an alpine species.
116. B. Bryum capillare – a very common species, in Europe and
North america; if B. Bryum billardieri be the same it
occurs also in N. New Holland.
7. B. Bryum caespititum – common in Europe & N. North america.
8. B. Bryum turbinatum – Europe, North & S. South america, Nepal?
9. B. Bryum coronatum – Cayenne, and Nepal, but perhaps this
species is not different from B. Bryum caespititum.
10. B. Bryum roseum. Europe, North america, South america
as at Rio Janeiro, – isles of France & Bourbon, Nepal
&c.
11. B. Bryum
commersonii erythrocaulon }
&
B. Bryum auberti} iles of France & Bourbon, & Rio Janeiro.
12. B. Bryum rostratum – Europe, North america, Nepal, &c.
Cinclidium stygium
only one species & confined to the north of Europe.

There are usually considered to be two European species of
this genus, one of them has been found in the united States.
Schwaegrichen
says there describes another species from
Arctic America, I am not acquainted with it, but I think
the other two only the same one species.

Two Species are found in the South of Europe, one belongs
to S. South america ( v. vide
Humb. Humboldt
Synpos. Synopsis
Kunth 1822–1825, I, 49 (Fabronia Polycarpa). ), another comes from
the Cape isle de Bourbon (? vide. Schwaegrichen Hedwig/Schwaegrichen 1816, 339 (Fabronia Persooni). .), & ano
ther from New Holland ? ( v. vide
Hook. Hooker musci Exot. Exotici
Hooker, W. J. 1818–1820, II , Tab. CLX (Fabronia Australis). ) – upon the
whole this genus belongs to warm climates.

There are two sections: the flat distichous -leaved
ones are all tropical, the others are variously spread.
of about 26 24 species in this section, scarcesly more than only
one or two or three are confined to Europe, 8 or 9 are confinded
to the united states, P. Pterogonium gracile & perhaps one or two
more are common to both countries. P. Pterogonium gracile has been also found in the isle de Bourbon
P. Pterogonium smithii of
Europe (middle & Southern parts) is found at as far as the Cape of
G. Good Hope, at in Brazil (Rio Janeiro) &c. P. Pterogonium julaceum of
N. North america is found I believe in Nepal. A few species
are peculiar to
S. South america, others to Nepal.

This genus is chiefly confined to Europe & north america.
But there are two or three a few species, formerly numbered
under this genus, but now made into separate genera, that
are found in the southern hemisphere. Two species also
still retained in Leucodon, but very dissimilar to it in
appearance are also found, the one in Peru ? ( v. vide
Leucad. Leucodon Tomen
tosus
Humbt. Humboldt & Kunth. Synopsis Kunth 1822–1825, I, 53. ), the other in New Holland.
L. Leucodon canariensis, now an Astradontium is found both in
Teneriffe & the isle de Bourbon.

Like all the other Hypnoid genera this is widely diffused.
N. Neckera crispa is found in Europe, North & South america, Teneriffe, and
probably widely found every where: N. Neckera cladorrhizans
is common to Europe & N. North america, & is I believe met
with in Nepal – N. Neckera dendroides originally found in the Sand
wich isles
is also occurs in Nepal. – N. Neckera viticulosa is
common to Europe & N. North america.

Only one or
two three species are found in Europe, & one of these
D. Daltonia pennata is found also in N. North america, and Jamaica, Guiana & Isle de Bourbon, &
probably in several places in the Southern hemisphere,
of the other species ( nearly 20 16 or 18 ) D. Daltonia undulata is found in
Jamaica, South america, and many other nearly tropical
countries, the others are chiefly local.
Found in the isle de Bourbon, and in Java.
Hookeria.

With the exception of
two
or three very a few
species, and there are nearly about
35 known, this genus may be said to be tropical.
H. Hookeria lucens is found however in Europe & N. North america; but
we believe no other species has yet been found there.
The only species considerably south of
H. Hookeria magellanica
occurs at the straits of Magellan, & H. Hookeria cristata & Tamarisci
is are only found
in New Zealand. – but the localities of some species are not
precisely known. The most widely diffused species is
H. Hookeria Tamarisci
the Hypnum Tamarisci of Swartz, (but not of Hedwig.), it is found in
Jamaica, S. South america, isle de Bourbon, Nepaul &c.

Of this genus it is impossible to give any account: Most
authors at present are in the habit of making the plants from
remote localities distinct if they have a slight difference in
appearance: it is my opinion however in this genus in particular
that soil & climate will make the same species vary so
much that it can scarcely be recognized.

To avoid disputes it may be better to say generally that
13 most of the European species have a counterpart in North america
and the a similar reciprocity takes place between the tropical
countries. Thus Neckera
H. Hypnum
dendroides in Europe corresponds to
H. Hypnum
(Climacium) americanum of the united states: Hypnum abietum to
H. Hypnum scitum: Hyp. Boscii to
H. Hypnum illecebrum to H. Hypnum Boscii: Hyp. Hypnum ser
pens to H. Hypnum radicale &c: In the tropics H. Hypnum gratum seems
generally spread: H. Hypnum pallidum of Humboldt corresponds to H. Hypnum serratum from
the isle de Bourbon: The species most diffused are Hyp. Hypnum pro
liferum, but this in the tropics often gives way to H. Hypnum fuciforme.
H. Hypnum cupressiforme is found every where; – in every country where
there are shady woods: As may be expected the tropical varieties
are more tender, but and approach to the Genus Hookeria, but
I cannot separate them. from

F. Fontinalis antipyretica & squamosa are common to Europe
& N. North America. F. Fontinalis falcata is peculiar to Lapland, and
F. Fontinalis capillacea to Pensylvania Pennsylvania .
is peculiar to Nepal.

what I said of Hypnum applies also here: scarcely
two people have agreed what are to be considered species.
But among those found every where P. Polytrichum commune holds
the first rank: From the North to the South arctic circles
there is scarcely a country but posesses it. P. Polytrichum juniferinum is
also nearly as common although few species at present
lie yet hithertho known in the Southern hemisphere, still I suspect
they them abound as much as in the Northern. A few species
as P. Polytrichum convolutum & its allies grow in the tropics.
only found in N. New Holland

1. Of nearly 800 species known, about about 200 or upwards
are confined to Europe: about 80 to north america: to
South america
about the including the islands on the
coast of Cayenne, about 80: To E East India & Nepal & the
To Nepal, East India, & the adjacent islands about
100 or 120 including a few not yet described: To the Cape
of Good Hope not above 25 or 30. A few species are very
14 very widely distributed, as Sphagnum latifolium and acuti
folium. Trichostomum lanuginosum, Dicranum bryoides, glaucum,
& soparium scoparium , Didymodon purpureum, Tortula ruralis, Barth
Barthramia fontana; Bryum argenteum, & roseum, Hyp
num cupressiforme, & Polytrichum commune.

2. of these the species most diffused grow in marshy places or
in shady woods.

3. Mosses gradually diminish in number towards the arctic cir
cles, and become also fewer towards the tropics, unless in
mountainous or moist climates. In temperate regions they
abound: & they there grow at every altitude fom the level of
the sea to the limits of perpetual snow.

4. A. In the arctic circle there are peculiar the genus Cinclidium,
a few Splachna, one Orthotrichum, one Voitia, a Fontinalis,
& one Polytrichum.

B. To the Northern or mountainious part of the temperate regions
we have several of the genus Splachnum, Dissodon, & Tayloria, a Voitia,
Bruchia, & several Polytricha, Grimmia, Trichostoma, Gymnosto
ma, & Conostomum.

C. To the middle of Europe we have confined some Phasca, one Splach
num, several Orthotricha, Tortulae, Weissiae, Dicrana,
Didymodontes, Barthramiae, Hypna &c: But there is scarce
ly one entire genus peculiar to this district.

D. To On the United states, we may make the same remark as to genera: But
there are peculiar some species of
Shascum Sphascum , Grimmiae, Weissiae, Pterogonium,
several Hypna, & one or two of Fontinalis.

E. To the South of Europe & much of Africa are confined three Fabronia, a Funaria,
a Gymnostomum, & a Bartramia & perhaps a fews others, but
this District has been litte examined.

F. To the west Indies, are confined a few species of the European
genera, as Dicranum, Tortula, Pterogonium, Neckera, Orthotrichum,
& Hookeria: some others of The Genus Calymperes calym are preculiar.

G. South america. The botany of the central part has been yet
little explored as to mosses: there exists the genera Gymostomum,
Polytrichum, Fabronia, Pterogonium, Neckera & several of the
genus Hookeria. The species are , generally speaking, seldom
found elsewhere.

15H. Nepal. There are here some Gymostoma, Tortulae, and
species, belonging to nearly all the European genera: two
genera Lyellia & Brachymenium are peculiar to this country,
very few of the species occur out of the country.

K. To new Holland & New Zealand
are belong several species belonging
to European genera: but the genera Dawsonia, Leptotheca,
and Leptostonum are peculiar, as well as the greater
proportion of the dendroid tribe of the Hypnoid family.

5. K. The genera most particularly belonging to and spread
in the tropics, are Calymperes, Orthotricha, Thesanomitrion,
Pterogonium, Daltonia, & Hookeria.

6. It must not be concluded that in the tropics there
are fewer species of mosses than in the temperate climates,
because hitherto the botany of these parts has not been so
particularly examined for mosses. The South of Africa, from
what Mr. Mister Burchell informs me is very poor in the
number of species of mosses.
